reference.shortdesc: The style-conflict element in a DITAVAL document declares the behavior to be used when one or more flagging methods collide on the same element..

section.title: Rendering expectations
section.p: The following table details how conflicts are resolved when different flagging methods are specified for the same element:

stentry.p: Use the color specified by the background-conflict-color attribute on the style-conflict element. If no background conflict color is specified, use a default color that is appropriate for the output format.

strow.stentry: Add all change bars that apply.

stentry.p: Use the color specified by the foreground-conflict-color attribute on the style-conflict element. If no foreground conflict color is specified, use a default color that is appropriate for the output format.

strow.stentry: Add all font styles that apply. If two different kinds of underline are used, default to the heaviest (double underline) and use the color that is specified by the foreground-conflict-color attribute. If no foreground conflict color is specified, use a default color that is appropriate for the output format.

section.title: Attributes
section.p:
The following attributes are available on this element:
background-conflict-color Specifies the color to be used when more than one background color applies to a single element. Colors can be entered by name or code.
foreground-conflict-color Specifies the color to be used when more than one color applies to a single element. Colors can be entered by name or code.

example.title: Example
example.p: The following code sample shows a DITAVAL document that specifies that a background color of #ffffb3 is used when there are conflicts:
example.codeblock: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <val> <style-conflict background-conflict-color="#ffffb3"/> <prop action="flag" att="platform" val="dita" backcolor="#ccffb3"/> <prop action="flag" att="platform" val="lwdita" backcolor="#ffe6ff"/> </val>
example.p: Any element that specifies a value of dita lwdita or lwdita dita is rendered with a light-yellow background color.
